ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more grammatical structures in Chinese and how to use them and improved my free form speaking.
Learned intermediate grammar structures and developed speaking skills.
Intermediate chinese conversation and reading and writing skills.
I learned a lot of Chinese that I didn't think I would learn so much. We covered a lot of topic, but one thing I really improved on was my grammar!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: Partner work in class helped with engagement and learning.
Weakness: At times, there was some confusion as to the grading methodology of certain assignments.
I loved CHNS L3. By far my favorite CHNS course yet! Good work balance and exposure to chinese!

Strength is that this class is small, so we have the chance to practice speaking every day! Weakness may be the huge workload, sometimes I feel like there's too much (even though class is everyday, the workload doesn't have to be so heavy everyday).

Strengths: High engagement, fun content
Weaknesses: Assignments don't prioritize learning sometimes

Some of the assignments are unjustly timed. I took a quiz that was less than 5 minutes long and there were more than 5 questions. It often felt stressful and it was more about memorizing than truly learning and reasoning through it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to someone who is willing to invest the time.
I would highly recommend! While L1 and L2 are very difficult, L3 is when I finally felt things click and the course helped facilitate that!
Yes!!! So important to learn a language, and it is so worthwhile learning Chinese!
If they are passionate about Chinese! There are many events, it's great.
